sen.j: 平 康頼（たいら の やすより、久安2年（1146年）? - 承久2年（1220年））は、平安時代の貴族。
sen.e: TAIRA no Yasuyori (1146?-1220) was ranked among the noble classes in the Heian period.
TAIRA no Yasuyori (1146?-1220) was among the noble classes in the Heian period.
sen.cmt: Don't need to make "ranked" passive.
sen.e: TAIRA no Yasuyori (c. 1146 - 1220) was a member of the noble class in the Heian period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 左大史・中原頼季（なかはらのよりすえ）の子。
sen.e: He was a child of the sadaishi (one of the government post) NAKAHARA no Yorisue.
He was a child of the sadaishi (a government post) NAKAHARA no Yorisue.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: He was a child of NAKAHARA no Yorisue who was Sadaishi (senior recorder of the left).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 検非違使兼衛門府。
sen.e: He obtained the post of kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) and emmonfu (palace gate guard).
He served in the posts of kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) and emmonfu (palace gate guard).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: He served in the posts of kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) and Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 平判官入道と称された。
sen.e: He was called Taira hangannyudo.
He was also called Taira hangannyudo.
sen.cmt: I think an "also" is needed here. Otherwise, it is not clear that it is Yasunori being discussed.
sen.e: He was also called Taira hangannyudo.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 明法道（法律）の家柄である中原氏に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born to the Nakahara clan which from the house standing of Myobodo (study of Codes).
He was born to the Nakahara clan which had the status of Myobodo (lawyers).
sen.cmt: OK
sen.e: He was born to the Nakahara clan which had the status of Myobodo (study of Codes).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 平家一門の中で有力な地位にある平保盛という人物が居たが、保盛と中原家とは密接な関係にあったようで、康頼は十代で保盛の家人となっている。
sen.e: Meanwhile there was a person named TAIRA no Yasumori in the Taira clan, who had gained a high-powered position, Yasumori and the Nakahara family apparently had a close relation, and so Yasuyori became a retainer of Yasumori in his teens.

Among the Tiara clan was TAIRA no Yasumori who held a high-powered position, and a seemingly close relationship between Yasumori and the Nakahara family led to Yasuyori becoming a retainer of Yasumori in his teens.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Among the Taira clan was TAIRA no Yasumori who held a high-powered position, and a seemingly close relationship between Yasumori and the Nakahara family led to Yasuyori becoming a retainer of Yasumori in his teens.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 保盛は長寛元年正月24日付で、越前の国司に任ぜられており、18歳の康頼も越前に派遣されて、この頃に主君から平の姓を賜与を受けたと思われる。
sen.e: Following the appointment of Yasumori to the kokushi (an officer of local government) in Echizen on January 24th, 1163, 18-year-old Yasuyori was also dispatched to Echizen, and it is believed that Yasuyori was granted the family name of Taira from his lord around this period.

When Yasumori was appointed as kokushi (provincial governer) of Echizen on January 24th, 1163, the 18-year-old Yasuyori was also dispatched to Echizen, and it is believed that Yasumori granted Yasuyori the family name of Taira around this time.
sen.cmt: Natural English. Also, from the translation of 14, I think kokushi is better described as "provincial governer".
sen.e: When Yasumori was appointed as provincial governor of Echizen Province on March 7, 1163, the 18-year-old Yasuyori was also dispatched to Echizen, and it is believed that Yasumori granted Yasuyori the family name of Taira around this time.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 保盛は仁安元年12月30日付で、尾張の国司に転任し、康頼を目代に昇格して派遣した。
sen.e: Yasumori was posted to the kokushi in Owari on December 30th, 1166, and dispatched Yasuyori after promoting him to the mokudai (deputy kokushi, or a deputy provincial governor).
Yasumori was appointed as kokushi of Owari on December 30th, 1166, and dispatched Yasuyori after promoting him to mokudai (deputy kokushi, or a deputy provincial governor).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Yasumori was appointed provincial governor of Owari Province on January 29, 1167, and dispatched Yasuyori after promoting him to deputy provincial governor.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: この尾張国知多郡野間の荘には源義朝（源頼朝の父）の墓があったが、誰も顧みる者も無く荒れるに任せていた。
sen.e: There was a grave of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo (father of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo) in a villa in Noma, Chita district, Owari Province, however the grave was utterly neglected because nobody paid attention to it.
There was a grave of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo (father of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo) in a villa in Noma, Chita district, Owari Province, but, with nobody to look after it, it had been utterly neglected.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: There was a grave of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo (father of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo) in a villa in Noma, Chita district, Owari Province, but, with nobody to look after it, it had been utterly neglected.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 義朝は平治の乱に破れ東国を目指して落ち延びる途中、相伝の家人長田父子に入浴を勧められて油断させられ湯殿で非業の死をとげる。
sen.e: Yoshitomo, when he was fleeing to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) after he lost Heiji no ran (Rebellion of Heiji), fell into the trap of taking a bath to relax, which was tenaciously recommended by father and son of the Osada family, who were retainers of the generations of the Genji family, and he was killed in the bathroom.

Yoshitomo, when fleeing to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) after losing Heiji no ran (Rebellion of Heiji), had fallen into the trap of taking a bath recommended to him by the father and son of the Osada family, hereditary retainers to the Genji family, and been killed in the bathroom.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Yoshitomo, when fleeing to Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) after losing the Heiji War, had fallen into the trap when he took a bath at the suggestion of the father and son of the Osada family, hereditary retainers to the Minamoto family, and was killed in the bathroom.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 康頼はこの敵将の墓を修理して堂を立て六口の僧を置き不断念仏を唱えさせ、その保護に水田三十町歩を寄進した。
sen.e: Yasuyori erected a do (temple to enshrine the lost soul) after he repaired the Yoshitomo's grave although he was an opponent, employed six monks to make them chant the Fudan nenbutsu (continual Buddhist invocation chanting), and donated 30 cho bu of paddy field to preserve the do.
sen.cmt: 六口の意味ですが，調べたところ六人の意味で使っているのでしょうか。町歩の歩を追加しました。単位はメートル法での換算が一般的かと考えました。また，文の書き出し部ですが敵将である義朝のイメージをだすには，義朝が主語の方がよいのではと考えました。
sen.e: Though Yoshimoto was an enemy, Yasuyori repaired Yoshitomo's grave, erected a do (temple to enshrine the lost soul), employed six monks and had them perform the Fudan nenbutsu (continual Buddhist chant), and donated 30 cho bu (about 30 ha) of paddy fields for the upkeep of the do.
sen.cmt: Natural English. Also, it is not clear what "cho bu" is referring to. Some explanation is necessary.
sen.e: Though Yoshimoto was an enemy, Yasuyori repaired Yoshitomo's grave, erected a temple to enshrine the lost soul, employed six monks and had them perform the continual nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) and donated about 297510 square meters of paddy fields for the upkeep of the shrine.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。用語集に合わせました。1町=9917平方メートルで計算しました。

sen.j: 当時、この噂は京にも聞こえ後白河上皇の耳にも達して、平康頼なる人物は目代ながら、武士道の礼節をわきまえた頼もしい若者との深い印象を与え、近習に取立てた。
sen.e: In those days, this praiseworthy story reached Kyoto, which also reached the retired Emperor Goshirakawa's ears and gave him the impression that TAIRA no Yasuyori was a trustworthy young man to understand the politeness of Bushido (the code of the samurai) despite he was still ranked with the mokudai, and he promoted Yasuyori to the kinju (attendant).
sen.cmt: andが必要かと考えました
sen.e: When this story reached Kyoto and the ears of retired Emperor Goshirakawa, he got the impression that TAIRA no Yasuyori, despite his rank of mokudai, was a trustworthy young man infused with the spirit of Bushido (the code of the samurai), and promoted him to the post of kinju (attendant).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: When this story reached Kyoto and the ears of Retired Emperor Goshirakawa, he got the impression that TAIRA no Yasuyori, despite his rank of deputy provincial governor, was a trustworthy young man infused with the spirit of Bushido (the code of the samurai), and promoted him to the post of kinju (attendant).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 検非違使兼左衛門大尉に任じられ、平判官と称した。
sen.e: Yasuyori was appointed police and judicial chief, saemon-no-taii (one of the government post) and called Taira hangan (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period).

Yasuyori was appointed police and judicial chief, saemon-no-taii (a government post) and given the title of Taira hangan (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period)).
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Yasuyori was appointed police and judicial chief, Saemon no daijo (Senior Lieutenant at the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and given the title of Taira hangan (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period)).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: この後には、鹿ケ谷事件で藤原成親、西光、俊寛らの平家打倒の密議に参加。
sen.e: Later, Yasuyori joined a secret conference plotted by FUJIWARA no Narichika, Saiko, Shunkan and others to plan the overthrow of the Heike family, which is called the Shishigatani plot.
Later, Yasuyori joined the plot, known as the Shishigatani plot, by FUJIWARA no Narichika, Saiko, Shunkan and others to overthrow the Heike family.
sen.cmt: Natural English. It also seems to me that the translation of "平家" should be "Taira family" and not "Heike".
sen.e: Later, Yasuyori joined the plot, known as the Shishigatani Incident, by FUJIWARA no Narichika, Saiko, Shunkan and others to overthrow the Taira family.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: その酒席で瓶子（へいし）が倒れるのを「平氏が倒れた」と喜んでいた。
sen.e: When he saw a heishi (sake bottle) fell in a drinking party, he was pleased and said, "the Taira family (when "Taira family" is written in Chinese characters, it can also be read as "heishi " in the pseudo-Chinese reading) was overthrown".

On seeing a heishi (sake bottle) fall over at a drinking party, he is said to have been pleased and remarked "The Heishi has fallen" (Heishi being another reading for the Chinese characters for "Taira clan").
sen.cmt: Natural English. Simplified explanation.
sen.e: On seeing a sake bottle (called heishi) fall over at a drinking party, he is said to have been pleased and remarked 'The Heishi has fallen' (Heishi being another reading for the Chinese characters for 'Taira clan').
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 密告によりことが漏れて康頼も捕縛される。
sen.e: The plot was leaked out through an anonymous report, and Yasuyori was captured with others.
The plot was leaked an anonymously, and Yasuyori and his co-conspirators were captured.
sen.cmt: Natural English.
sen.e: The story was leaked anonymously, and Yasuyori and his co-conspirators were captured.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 俊寛、藤原成経と共に薩摩国鬼界ヶ島へ流された。
sen.e: He was banished to Kikaiga-shima Island, Satsuma Province along with Shunkan and FUJIWARA no Naritsune.
He was banished to Kikaiga-shima Island, Satsuma Province along with Shunkan and FUJIWARA no Naritsune.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He was banished to Kikaiga-shima Island, Satsuma Province along with Shunkan and FUJIWARA no Naritsune.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: （鹿ケ谷の陰謀）。
sen.e: "the Shishigatani plot"
"the Shishigatani plot"
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: (the Shishigatani plot)
sen.cmt: 括弧に変更しました。

sen.j: 『平家物語』によると、信仰心の厚かった康頼は流罪にあたり出家入道し性照と号した。
sen.e: According to "Heike Monogatari" (the tale of the Heike), responding to the banishment, pious Yasuyori entered into priesthood and named himself Shosho.
According to "Heike Monogatari" (the tale of the Heike), on being banished, the ever pious Yasuyori entered into priesthood and named himself Shosho.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: According to "Heike Monogatari" (the Tale of the Heike), on being banished, the ever pious Yasuyori entered into priesthood and took the name Shosho.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 京を懐かしむ日々の中で成経と康頼は千本の卒塔婆に望郷の歌を記し海に流すこと思い立つ。
sen.e: While Naritsune and Yasuyori longed for Kyoto day after day, they thought of noting down nostalgic poems on thousand pieces of stupa to throw them into the sea.

Naritsune and Yasuyori had a constant longing to return to Kyoto and came up with the idea of noting down nostalgic poems on a thousand stupa (long and narrow wooden tablets), and throwing them into the sea.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Naritsune and Yasuyori had a constant longing to return to Kyoto and came up with the idea of noting down nostalgic poems on a thousand stupa (long and narrow wooden tablets), and throwing them into the sea.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 一本の卒塔婆が安芸国厳島に流れ着き、これに心を打たれた平清盛は赦免を行う。
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori was moved by a poem noted down on a stupa, which had been washed up on the shore of Itsukushima in the Aki Province, and ordered the remission of banishment.
One of the stupa washed up on the shore of Itsukushima in Aki Province, and TAIRA no Kiyomori was so moved by the poem on it that he ordered the remission of the banishment.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: One of the stupa washed up on the shore of Itsukushima in Aki Province, and TAIRA no Kiyomori was so moved by the poem on it that he ordered the remission of the banishment.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 治承2年（1178年）に赦免船が来て成経と康頼だけは赦免され京へ戻るが、俊寛は許されなかった。
sen.e: In 1178, only Naritsune and Yasuyori were pardoned and returned to Kyoto by a vessel prepared for the pardoned people, however Shunkan alone was not pardoned.
In 1178, Naritsune and Yasuyori were pardoned and returned to Kyoto in a specially prepared vessel, but Shunkan was not pardoned.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In 1178, Naritsune and Yasuyori were pardoned and returned to Kyoto in a specially prepared vessel, but Shunkan was not pardoned.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 帰京後は伯母が尼となって身を寄せる東山の双林寺で仏教説話集『宝物集』を編集執筆する。
sen.e: After having returned to Kyoto, he wrote and edited a collection of Buddhist Tales, "Hobutsushu" (Yasuyori's Collection of Treasures) in Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward where his aunt lived, who had become a nun.

After returning to Kyoto, he wrote and edited a collection of Buddhist Tales called "Hobutsushu" (Yasuyori's Collection of Treasures) in Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward where his aunt had become a nun.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: After returning to Kyoto, he wrote and edited a collection of Buddhist Tales called "Hobutsushu" (Yasuyori's Collection of Treasures) in Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama where his aunt had become a nun.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 文治2年（1186年）には源頼朝は、父義朝の墓を弔った平康頼を阿波国麻殖保の保司の職に任命した。
sen.e: In 1186, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo appointed TAIRA no Yasuyori to the hoji (an officer governing the territory under the direct control of the bakufu) of Oe-no-ho (ho is a territory directly controlled by the bakufu) in Awa Province, because Yoritomo had known that Yasuyori hold Buddhist memorial service for the soul of Yoritomo's father.
sen.cmt: webの保司の説明が不十分と思われたのでこのように書きました。
sen.e: In 1186, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo appointed TAIRA no Yasuyori as hoji (officer governing the territory under the direct control of the bakufu) of Oe-no-ho (a territory directly controlled by the bakufu) in Awa Province, because Yoritomo knew that Yasuyori had held a Buddhist memorial service for the soul of Yoritomo's father.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In 1186, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo appointed TAIRA no Yasuyori as hoji (officer governing the territory under the direct control of the bakufu) of Oe-no-ho (a territory directly controlled by the bakufu) in Awa Province, because Yoritomo knew that Yasuyori had held a Buddhist memorial service for the soul of Yoritomo's father.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 康頼はすでに41歳になっていた。
sen.e: He was already 41years old.
He was already 41years old.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Yasuyori was already 41 years old.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 康頼は保司庁、鼓楼、六坊寺を建て、熊野神社を勧請し、鬼界山補陀らく寺を建てたがその名が示す通り鬼界が島の俊寛を弔うものであり、又、慈眼山玉林寺を建て源平の戦いで死んだ者を源平の区別無く供養したと云われる。
sen.e: Besides the erection of the hoji office, Koro Tower and Rokubo-ji Temple as well as branch shrines of Kumano-jinja Shrine for deity, Yasuyori built Mt. Kikai Fudaraku-ji Temple (when the name of this temple is written in Chinese characters, it means "a temple for Kannon Worship", regarding Kikaiga-shima Island as the jodo (the pure land of Kannon)") to mourn for Shunkan in Kikaiga-shima Island, furthermore he built Gyokurin-ji Temple of Mt.Jigenzan and hold memorial services for the souls who were killed in the Gempei (the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan) War regardless of clans.
sen.cmt: 補陀らく寺がwebでは「ほだらく」でしたが調べると「ふだらく」なので訂正しました。また「この寺の名前が示す通り・・」の内容の記載ですが，漢字以外では「その名が示す」ということが理解できないと思われこのようにしました。
sen.e: Besides building the hoji office, Koro Tower, Rokubo-ji Temple and branch shrines of Kumano-jinja Shrine, Yasuyori built Mt. Kikai Fudaraku-ji Temple to mourn for Shunkan in Kikaiga-shima Island (Fudaraku-ji means "temple for Kannon Worship" and Kikaiga-shima was regarded as the jodo (pure land of Kannon)); and built Gyokurin-ji Temple on Mt.Jigenzan where he held memorial services for all those killed in the Gempei War (war between the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan) irrespective of their allegiances.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Besides building the hoji office, Koro Tower, Rokubo-ji Temple and branch shrines of Kumano-jinja Shrine, Yasuyori built Fudaraku-ji Temple on Mt. Kikai to mourn for Shunkan in Kikaiga-shima Island (Fudaraku-ji means "temple for Kannon Worship" and Kikaiga-shima was regarded as the jodo (pure land of Kannon)); and built Gyokurin-ji Temple on Mt.Jigen where he held memorial services for all those killed in the Genpei War (war between the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan) irrespective of their allegiances.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 康頼は承久2年（1220年）頃、75歳で没し、一町地と呼ばれる所で火葬される。
sen.e: Yasuyori died around 1220 at the age of 75 and was cremated at a place called Icchochi.
Yasuyori died around 1220 at the age of 75 and was cremated at a place called Ichochi.
sen.cmt: I think "Icchoci" is better written as "Ichochi"
sen.e: Yasuyori died around 1220 at the age of 75 and was cremated at a place called Ichochi.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 康頼神社の脇に墓があり、遺言で鶴田氏が康頼神社を建て主君を神として祀り代々祭司を務めた。
sen.e: Yasuyori's grave is placed aside Yasuyori-jinja Shrine, which was erected by the Tsuruta clan to deify their lord following Yasuyori's will, and they succeeded the priest of the shrine for generations.
sen.cmt: 康頼神社の脇の墓はだれの墓なのか不明です。
sen.e: Yasuyori's grave was placed next to Yasuyori-jinja Shrine which was erected according to Yasuyori's will by the Tsuruta clan to deify their lord and was served by generations of priests from the Tsurata clan.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Yasuyori's grave was placed next to Yasuyori-jinja Shrine which was erected according to Yasuyori's will by the Tsuruta clan to deify their lord and was served by generations of priests from the Tsuruta clan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 遺骨は分骨されて、京都東山の双林寺にも埋葬された。
sen.e: His cremains were separated and buried also at Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward.
His cremains were separated, with a portion also being buried at Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: His cremains were separated, with a portion also being buried at Sorin-ji Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 康頼神社の脇に三基の五輪塔があるが、康頼の母、康頼、俊寛の三人のものという。
sen.e: It is believed that three bodies of gorinto (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) erected aside Yasuyori-jinja Shrine are for Yasuyori's mother, Yasuyori and Shunkan respectively.
sen.cmt: 基の単位の表現方法が不明です。
sen.e: It is believed that the three gorinto (gravestone composed of five piled-up stone pieces) erected aside Yasuyori-jinja Shrine are for Yasuyori's mother, Yasuyori and Shunkan.
sen.cmt: Natural English. "Respectively" is not required here.
sen.e: It is believed that the three gravestones composed of five piled-up stone pieces erected aside Yasuyori-jinja Shrine are for Yasuyori's mother, Yasuyori and Shunkan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 清盛の怒りが解けず、鬼界が島に一人残された俊寛は、数年後に都から、はるばる訪ねて来た弟子の有王の世話をうけながら、自ら絶食して生命を絶った。
sen.e: Shunkan, who was left alone in Kikaiga-shima Island because Kiyomori's anger was not allayed, killed himself by fasting several years later, although he had been under the care of his disciple Ario (有王), who had come all the way from Kyoto to meet Shunkan.
sen.cmt: 有王の読み方がわかりません
sen.e: Shunkan, initally alone in Kikaiga-shima Island because of Kiyomori's continuing anger towards him, was visted after a few years by his pupil Ario (有王) who came all the way from Kyoto to see him; but Shunkan starved himself to death while in Ario's care.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Shunkan, who was alone in Kikaiga-shima Island because of Kiyomori's continuing anger towards him, was visited after a few years by his pupil Ario who came all the way from Kyoto to see him; but Shunkan starved himself to death while in Ario's care.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 有王は主人を火葬して骨を持ち帰り、高野山に埋葬したが、康頼はその分骨をゆずり受けて、壇の下に葬ったとも言われている。
sen.e: Meanwhile Ario (有王) returned to Kyoto with his master's cremains and buried them in Koya-san Mountain, it is also said that Yasuyori obtained Shunkan's separated ashes by transfer and buried them under the base stone of Shunkan's gorinto.
sen.cmt: 有王の読み方がわかりません。壇の下は文脈から考えると五輪塔の下と思われるのですが。
sen.e: Ario (有王) brought back his master's cremains and buried them on Koya-san Mountain, but Yasuyori is also said to have obtained a portion and buried them under the base stone of Shunkan's gorinto.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Ario brought back his master's cremains and buried them on Mt. Koya, but Yasuyori is also said to have obtained a portion and buried them under the base stone of Shunkan's gravestone composed of five piled-up stone pieces.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。用語集に合わせました。前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 二代目の清基は承元年中に保司職を継承したが、後に、承久の乱に後鳥羽上皇方に加わったとして保司職を解任された。
sen.e: Kiyomoto (清基), the second head of the house, succeeded as the hoji during Jogen period, however later, he was removed from the hoji on suspicion of taking sides with the retired Emperor Gotoba in Jokyu Rebellion.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処. 清基の読み方がわかりません。
sen.e: Kiyomoto (清基), the second head of the house, inherited the post of hoji during Jogen period, but he was later dismissed on suspicion of siding with the retired Emperor Gotoba in the Jokyu Rebellion.
sen.cmt: Natural English. "charge" is the word used when the case is brought to court. It is not used to described the crime after judgement.
sen.e: Kiyomoto, the second head of the house, inherited the post of hoji during 1207 and 1210, but he was later dismissed on suspicion of siding with the Retired Emperor Gotoba in the Jokyu War.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。和暦をのぞき、用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 彼はそれを不服として無実を鎌倉に訴えたが、裁判は破れ、偽りを述べた罪で鎌倉で首を斬られた。
sen.e: Although he protested against the allegation and pleaded his innocent to Kamakura, he lost the suit and was decapitated in Kamakura on a charge of perjury.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Although he denied the allegation and pleaded his innocence to Kamakura, he lost his case and was decapitated in Kamakura for perjury.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: Although he denied the allegation and pleaded his innocence to Kamakura, he lost his case and was decapitated in Kamakura for perjury.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『吾妻鏡』二十六に、承久3年（1221年）10月28日、平清基麻植保没収の記事がある。
sen.e: In the 26th volume of "Azuma Kagami" (Mirror of Azuma, the chronicle of Azuma), there is a description that TAIRA no Kiyomoto (清基) forfeited Oe-no-ho on October 28th, 1221.
sen.cmt: 吾妻鏡26巻と解釈しました。清基の読み方が不明です。
sen.e: In the 26th volume of "Azuma Kagami" (Mirror of Azuma, the chronicle of Azuma), it is stated that TAIRA no Kiyomoto (清基) forfeited Oe-no-ho on October 28th, 1221.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: In the 26th volume of "Azuma Kagami"(The Mirror of the East), it is stated that TAIRA no Kiyomoto forfeited Oe-no-ho on November 20, 1221.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。用語集に合わせ、グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 三代目の俊職は官職を失って浪々の身となり京に出たが、承久の変の敗者には仕える主人も現れなかった。
sen.e: Having lost the government post and become an unemployed person, the third house head Toshimoto went to Kyoto, however he, a loser in Jokyu Rebellion, could not find a lord to serve, and in the end, he was captured after he conspired with insurgents and killed Shiro IGU with poisoned arrows.

No longer having the government post, the third head of the family, Toshimoto, went to Kyoto but, as a member of the losing side in the Jokyu Rebellion, was unable to find a lord to serve. He then joined an insurgency, killed Shiro IGU with poisoned arrows, and was captured.
sen.cmt: I think this is better as two sentences.
sen.e: No longer having the government post, the third head of the family, Toshimoto, went to Kyoto but, as a member of the losing side in the Jokyu War, was unable to find a lord to serve.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: その後、賊徒の輩と徒党を組み、伊具四郎を毒矢で射殺し捕らえられた。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He then joined an insurgency, killed Shiro IGU with poisoned arrows, and was captured.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 首謀者の諏訪刑部左門は斬首となり、俊職と牧左衛門は、昔、祖父の康頼が流されていた鬼界が島に流されて消息を絶ち、森藤の平家は絶家した。
sen.e: SUWA no gyobu Samon, the mastermind of the incident, was decapitated, and Toshimoto and Saemon MAKI were banished to Kikaiga-shima Island where Toshimoto's grandfather Yasuyori had also been banished, however, nothing had been heard of Toshimoto afterward, and as a result, the Morifuji domain (Taira clan) died out.

SUWA no gyobu Samon, the mastermind of the incident, was decapitated, and Toshimoto and Saemon MAKI were, like Toshimoto's grandfather Yasuyori, banished to Kikaiga-shima Island, whereupon nothing more was heard of Toshimoto and and the Taira clan of the Morafuji domain died out.
sen.cmt: Natural English
sen.e: SUWA no gyobu Samon, the mastermind of the incident, was decapitated, and Toshimoto and Saemon MAKI were, like Toshimoto's grandfather Yasuyori, banished to Kikaiga-shima Island, whereupon nothing more was heard of Toshimoto; and the Taira clan of the Morifuji died out.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 俊職のおじ康利は一族をまとめて森藤を引き払い、昔、父康頼が赴任した越前国足羽郡の縁者を頼って彼の地へ去り、康利は出家して探嶺院に入った。
sen.e: Leaning on relatives, Yasutoshi, Toshimoto's uncle, left Morifuji with his clan for Asuha (足羽) district, Echizen Province where his father Yasuyori had served, and Yasutoshi became a priest and entered Tanrei-in (探嶺院) Temple. His child Yasutsuna also became a priest to succeed his father and changed Tanrei-in (探嶺院) Temple 's name to Jodo Shinshu sect Mt. Shinko-san Josho-ji Temple, and then became the gon daisozu (Junior prelate) as well as the founder of this temple, furthermore, his descendants became priests for generations and gained fame.
sen.cmt: 探嶺院，足羽の読み方が不明です。一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Yasutoshi, Toshimoto's uncle, gathered his family together, left Morifuji for Asuha (足羽) district in Echizen Province where his father Yasuyori had served, and joined Tanrei-in (探嶺院) Temple as a priest. His son Yasutsuna followed him into the priesthood, renaming Tanrei-in (探嶺院) Temple as Mt. Shinko-san Josho-ji Temple (Jodo Shinshu sect) and thereby becoming founder and gon daisozu (Junior prelate) of the same. Thereafter, Yasutsuna's descendants entered the priesthood and made a name for the family.
sen.cmt: I split the sentence again and tried to use more natural English.
sen.e: Yasutoshi, Toshimoto's uncle, gathered his family together, left Morifuji for Asuha district in Echizen Province where his father Yasuyori had served, and joined Tanrei-in Temple as a priest.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: その子の康綱も出家して後を継ぎ、探嶺院を浄土真宗心光山常照寺と改め、権大僧都となり、同寺の開祖となり、子孫は代々僧となって名を上げた。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: His son Yasutsuna followed him into the priesthood, renaming Tanrei-in Temple Josho-ji Temple (Jodo Shinshu sect) on Mt. Shinko and thereby becoming founder and Gon Daisozu (the provisional highest grade that can be held by one who has reached the second highest rank in the hierarchy of Buddhist priests); thereafter, Yasutsuna's descendants entered the priesthood and made a name for the family.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。用語集に合わせました。

tit.j: 大坊創建の事情について
tit.e: Circumstances on the erection of daibo (memorial column)
tit.cmt: 大坊の説明が必要と思われましたがwebにないため，文から判断しました。「ついて」の意味合いをだすためにonを追加しました。
tit.e: On the erection of daibo (memorial column)
tit.cmt: I think "circumstances" is better omitted here.
tit.e: On the construction of the memorial column.
tit.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 愛知県美浜町 (愛知県)の野間大坊康頼による大坊創建の事情については、『吾妻鏡』に詳しく述べられている。
sen.e: "Azuma Kagami" describes in detail the circumstances on the erection of the daibo by Nomadaibo Yasuyori in Mihama City, Aichi Prefecture, meanwhile, the story has been passed down that Yoritomo erected the memorial column as a token of his gratitude for Yasuyori's praiseworthy conduct when Yoritomo visited his father Yoshitomo's mausoleum in 1190, although there is some doubt.
sen.cmt: commentにdaiboの説明を，とあったため追加しましたが，直上の文に説明を加えてあるのですが必要でしょうか。さらにwhen以下が長くどこにかかるのかわかりづらいと考え，1190年を先に記載しました。またas a tokenのaを追加しました。
sen.e: "Azuma Kagami" describes in detail the erection of the daibo (memorial column) by Nomadaibo Yasuyori in Mihama City, Aichi Prefecture. However, there is also a story that Yoritomo built it as a token of his gratitude for Yasuyori's excellent conduct in 1190, when Yoritomo visited his father Yoshitomo's mausoleum. However, questions remain.
sen.cmt: Natural English. Explanation of "daibo" required.
sen.e: "Azuma Kagami" describes in detail the construction of the memorial column in Noma by Yasuyori in Mihama Town, Aichi Prefecture.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。原文に合わせました。

sen.j: また、頼朝が父義朝の廟所に参拝した折（建久元年）、その奇特な行いを謝して設けた供養塔と言い伝えられているが、疑問点がある。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: There is also a story that Yoritomo built it as a token of his gratitude for Yasuyori's excellent conduct in 1190, when Yoritomo visited his father's (Yoshitomo's) mausoleum, however questions remain.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。

sen.j: 頼朝は正治元年1月に53歳で死亡している。
sen.e: Yasuyori died at the age of 53 in January 1199.
Yoritomo died at the age of 53 in January 1199.
sen.cmt: Name mistaken
sen.e: Yoritomo died at the age of 53 in February 1199.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 当時康頼はまだ健在で、その後20年も生きていることから、頼朝が康頼の供養塔を建てるはずがない。
sen.e: It is unlikely that Yoritomo erected a memorial column for Yasuyori, because Yasuyori was well at that time and could live for more 20 years.
sen.cmt: for a further のaを消しました
sen.e: When Yoritomo died, Yasuyori was still alive and would live for further 20 years, and thus Yoritomo could not possibly have erected a memorial column for Yasuyori.
sen.cmt: Natural Enlglish.
sen.e: When Yoritomo died, Yasuyori was still alive and would live for a further 20 years, and thus Yoritomo could not possibly have erected a memorial column for Yasuyori.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 明治の末頃、阿波史の著者手束愛次郎も疑問をもち、当時の知多郡役所に調査を依頼した。
sen.e: Around the end of the Meiji period, when Aijirou TEZUKA, an author of the History of Awa Province, had doubts and asked the government office of Chita district to examine this story, he received the following answers; Yoritomo rebuilt his father Yoshitomo's grave, which had been in Omido-ji Temple in Noma, as well as his retainers' graves in 1190.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Around the end of the Meiji period, when Aijirou TEZUKA, the author of the History of Awa Province had doubts about this story and asked the government office of Chita district to investigate it. He was told that Yoritomo had rebuilt his father Yoshitomo's grave, which had been in Omido-ji Temple in Noma, and his retainers' grave in 1190.
sen.cmt: Natural Enlglish.
sen.e: Around the end of the Meiji period, Aijiro TEZUKA, the author of the History of Awa Province had doubts about this story and asked the government office of Chita district to investigate it.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 回答は、次の通りであったという。
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He was told as follows.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。一旦1文に戻してから原文を分割しなおしました。

sen.j: 「頼朝は建久元年に、野間の大御堂寺にあった父義朝の墓と、家臣の墓を改築した。」
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Yoritomo had rebuilt his father Yoshitomo's grave, which had been in Omido-ji Temple in Noma, and his retainers' grave in 1190.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。原文に「」を付けました。

sen.j: 「それが後年になって、平康頼が義朝の墓（この墓でなく以前にあった墓）が荒れているのを修理して、堂宇を建て（大御堂寺の前身）水田三十町歩を寄進したという話の方が有名になり、家臣の供養塔を康頼の墓と誤り伝えたものである。」
sen.e: However later, the story had become more widely known that TAIRA no Yasuyori repaired the neglected grave of Yoshitomo (former grave, not this grave), erected a temple building (the predecessor of Omido-ji Temple) and donated 30 cho bu of paddy field, therefore the retainers' memorial column was mistaken for Yasuyoi's grave and as a result wrong story has been passed down.
sen.cmt: 町歩の歩を追加しました。「話が有名になり」を過去分詞を使用しました。また記載が家臣の供養塔なのでgraveを訂正しました
sen.e: Later, however, the story that TAIRA no Yasuyori repaired the neglected grave of Yoshitomo, erected a temple building (the predecessor of Omido-ji Temple) and donated 30 cho bu of paddy fields had become more widely known, with the result that the retainers' memorial column was mistaken for Yasuyori's grave.
sen.cmt: Natural English.
sen.e: Later, however, the story that TAIRA no Yasuyori repaired the neglected grave of Yoshitomo, erected a temple building (the predecessor of Omido-ji Temple) and donated 297510 square meters of paddy fields had become more widely known, with the result that the retainers' memorial column was mistaken for Yasuyori's grave.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。文字化けを直しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。原文に「」を付けました。

sen.j: 「平康頼は当地で死亡しておらず、墓とは何の関係もない」
sen.e: Furthermore the government office added that TAIRA no Yasuyori had no relation with the grave because he did not die in this district.
sen.cmt: have connection with としてto を訂正しました。
sen.e: The government office added that TAIRA no Yasuyori did not die in the district and therefore had no connection with the grave.
sen.cmt: Natural Enlglish.
sen.e: TAIRA no Yasuyori did not die in the district and therefore had no connection with the grave.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。一原文一訳文の例外対処。原文に「」を付けました。

sen.j: 伝承にいう頼朝が建てたものではなく、後になって、寺に関係した者が、大御堂寺創建者としての康頼を供養して立てたもののようである。
sen.e: The memorial column was not erected by Yoritomo contrary to the story passed down, and it seems that people who related to the temple erected the column for the repose of Yasuyori's soul, respecting him as a founder of Omido-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Contrary to を用い，さらにhave connection withに訂正するために関係代名詞を使用しました。
sen.e: Contrary to the story, the memorial column was not erected by Yoritomo but by people who had a connection with the temple out of respect for Yasuyori as the founder of Omido-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Natural Enlglish.
sen.e: Contrary to the story, the memorial column was not erected by Yoritomo but by people who had a connection with the temple out of respect for Yasuyori as the founder of Omido-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。
